question.text: A mixture of two gasses <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> is kept in a vessel which is maintained at a temperature <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi></math>. In the vessel there are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>N</mi></math> molecules each of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math>, of the gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>N</mi></math> molecules each of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> of the gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>. The mean square velocity of the molecules of the gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and the mean square velocity of the molecules of the gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> along the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> direction is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><msup><mi>w</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math> is

solution.text:
Mean kinetic energy of the two types of molecules should be equal. The mean square velocity of A type molecules =ω2+ω2+ω2=3ω2

Therefore, 12m3ω2=122mv2

This gives ω2v2=23
